links.title: Reformed Esperanto - Wikipedia
links.description: Reformed Esperanto, or Esperanto 1894, is an Esperantido, a constructed language derived from Esperanto. It is notable as the only complete Esperantido created by the original creator of Esperanto, L. L. Zamenhof. Although Zamenhof's stated preference was to avoid any discussion of changes, he was put under considerable pressure, including financial, to respond to the diverse reforms proposed by others. Reluctantly he decided to present a reforme...

¬ª Exploring Zork, Part 1 The Digital Antiquarian
links.description: I‚Äôve personally never found detailed accounts of other people‚Äôs experiences in videogames all that compelling. Like a Chris Farley interview, they mostly tend to end up as all anecdote and little narrative substance. I‚Äôve therefore shied away from that approach for this blog. I do, however, want to examine Zork in some depth, and in a way that goes beyond just a review. So, I thought I would write these posts as a sort of guided tour of the game....
links.original_title: Exploring Zork, Part 1

links.title: ¬ª Exploring Zork, Part 2 The Digital Antiquarian
links.description: Today we‚Äôll tackle the meat of Zork‚Äòs Great Underground Empire, shown on the map below.

links.title: ¬ª Exploring Zork, Part 3 The Digital Antiquarian
links.description: Today we‚Äôll finish up with Zork. That means plunging into the only big, completely traditional maze in the Infocom canon. And it‚Äôs a nasty one; apparently they decided that if you‚Äôre only going to do one, you might as well do it up right.

links.title: ¬ª The Roots of Infocom The Digital Antiquarian
¬ª The Birth of Infocom The Digital Antiquarian
links.description: As the Dynamic Modeling Group put the final touches on Zork and put it to bed at last, it was beginning to feel like the end of an era at MIT. Marc Blank was about to graduate medical school and begin his residency in Pittsburgh, which would make extensive MIT hacking impossible even given his seemingly superhuman capacities. Others were finishing their own degree programs at MIT, or just running out of justifications for forestalling ‚Äúreal‚Äù care...

links.title: ¬ª ZIL and the Z-Machine The Digital Antiquarian
links.description: When we left off last time, Marc Blank and Joel Berez were considering how to bring Zork to the microcomputer. Really, they were trying to solve three interrelated problems. At the risk of being pedantic, let me lay out them for you:

links.title: ¬ª Selling Zork The Digital Antiquarian
links.description: When we left off, it was late summer, 1979, and seven of the nine partners involved with Infocom were living in Boston, working various day jobs, and discussing as time allowed just what the newly minted company should actually do. Meanwhile, the other two partners, Marc Blank and Joel Berez, were living in Pittsburgh and doing something more practical about the question, designing ‚Äî entirely on paper at this stage ‚Äî a system for getting Zork (or...

links.description: In traditional Japanese aesthetics, wabi-sabi (‰æòÂØÇ) is a world view centered on the acceptance of transience and imperfection.[2] The aesthetic is sometimes described as one of beauty that is "imperfect, impermanent, and incomplete".[3] It is a concept derived from the Buddhist teaching of the three marks of existence (‰∏âÊ≥ïÂç∞, sanb≈çin), specifically impermanence (ÁÑ°Â∏∏, muj≈ç), suffering (Ëã¶, ku) and emptiness or absence of self-nature (Á©∫, k≈´).

links.title: Biblical languages - Wikipedia
links.description: Biblical languages are any of the languages employed in the original writings of the Bible. Partially owing to the significance of the Bible in society, Biblical languages are studied more widely than many other dead languages. Furthermore, some debates exist as to which language is the original language of a particular passage, and about whether a term has been properly translated from an ancient language into modern editions of the Bible. links.title: Letterform Archive ‚Äì Inventing the Adlam Script / Designing Type for a Society in Flux
links.description: In 1989, two brothers in Guinea, aged 10 and 14, invented an alphabet from scratch for their native language. Pular (and Fulfulde) were spoken by millions of Fula people dispersed across Western Africa, but had no writing system of their own. Within a few years, the boys‚Äô script spread like wildfire, as a culture embraced a new literacy. The alphabet is called ADLaM (or Adlam) after its first four letters and an acronym for a phrase meaning ‚Äúthe ...

links.title: J can look like APL or English
links.description:
J is a concise, interpreted array programming language which looks infamously
like line noise. It is the successor to APL, which is a concise, interpreted
array programming language which looks infamously like hieroglyphics.
